emails.subject: Wing test needed ASAP!
emails.body: Hey, Flairbus are on my back about their latest wing design. I need you to send over the first natural frequency by tomorrow. I'd recommend estimating frequency from the unforced time-domain response. Have a look in your toolkit and see what you can do.

results.name: First natural frequency
results.praise: Nice one! The client will be pleased with such a quick turnaround.

feedback.message: Hmm, your measured natural frequency is not quite right. Remember, frequency is 1/T, where T is the period of a single oscillation.
Try again, making sure to maximise your sampling frequency to get the highest possible measurement resolution.
Our in-house testing gives a first natural frequency of 100 Hz.

emails.subject: Modal test data needed
emails.body: I need a quick and rough estimate of the natural frequencies of the wing before my next stakeholder meeting. Please setup a test and choose an appropriate excitation method (NOTE: the wing is too stiff to execute free vibration testing in this case). Time is of the essence!

results.name: Excitation type
results.praise: Great! A hammer test provides a quick and simple test considering the constraints of the task.

feedback.message: The method you've chosen would take too long. Try another.
Since we are not too concerned with accuracy at the moment, a much simpler and excitation method can be used.
Hammer testing is the correct method.

results.name: Tip hardness
results.praise: Yes, well done! Tip 2 has a bandwidth of x-y Hz enabling all three expected modes to be excited

feedback.message: A harder tip is able to excite a wider range of natural frequencies.
Check the excitation bandwidth of the tip.
Tip 2 is correct as it enables excitation of all three modes.

results.name: Second natural frequency
results.praise: Correct! You successfully setup an appropriate test and employed the discrete Fourier transform.

feedback.message: That doesn't seem to match our simulations. Make sure you are using Hammer testing.
Not quite, read carefully off the DFT graph.
Our in-house testing gives a second natural frequency of 100 Hz. Press back to continue.

emails.subject: Modelling vibration caused by engine
emails.body: In an aircraft wing, the engine (which vibrates a lot!) is usually located at the middle of the wing. Conduct a modal test to simulate the dynamics. Click 'Send Results' for a list of required data.

results.name: Experimental setup
results.praise: Nice one! You have setup the test correctly.

feedback.message: Not quite, make sure you are exciting the structure from where the engine would be located.

results.name: Response frequency
results.praise: Oh no, you got it wrong. However, it seems that it is not your fault, there is something wrong with the measured data!

feedback.message: Not quite, make sure you are exciting the structure from where the engine would be located.

results.name: What error can cause the frequency of the response to be measured incorrectly?
results.praise: Correct! Aliasing occurs when the signal contains frequency content at greater than half the sampling frequency. This is why the response frequency is measured incorrectly.

feedback.message: Unfortunately that is not correct.
Unfortunately that is not correct.
Aliasing is the correct answer.

emails.subject: We need modal damping ratios!
emails.body: Hello, I've heard big things about your modal testing expertise. Please can you produce a Nyquist plot and use it to estimate modal damping ratios?

results.name: Radius of the circle
results.praise: That is correct! Since the circle is centred on the real axis and starts from the origin, the radius is simply the x-value of the centre coordinate.

feedback.message: Not quite, maybe try a different excitation method to produce a higher resolution Nyquist plot.
Unfortunately that is not correct. Try using Sine sweep with maximum sampling frequency.
Our finite element simulations give a radius of 20.

results.name: Third natural frequency
results.praise: Well done! The natural frequency is where the mobility Nyquist plot crosses the real axis. This is also where the sweep rate is at its maximum.

feedback.message: Not quite, look for the frequency where the sweep rate is at its maximum.
Try reading off the frequency where the circle crosses the real axis.
The third natural frequency should be roughly 200 Hz.

results.name: Third modal damping ratio
results.praise: Spot on! This is the most accurate estimate of zeta from the plot.

feedback.message: It might be easier to find the angle subtended from the origin to the point of interest and use angle identities.
Use the pair of points closest to the resonance point for more accurate estimate of damping.
The third modal damping ratio is expected to be around 20%.
